title: A question for all you tech savvy people.
body: So due to unfortunate circumstances, I can still play League on my normal home wifi SOMETIMES. And am now forced to play League of some other connection on other times, was just wondering, this might be the stupidest question thay anyone in the universe has ever asked, but would a portable usb modem be enough to run League smoothly?

replies.body:
Hey dude, dunno if you're still thinking about doing this, but if it's any help I often play league using my Vodafone iPhone5S hotspot. 

Usually fluctuates around the 37-60ms ping mark, occasionally floats up to ~250ms if my signal drops below 3 bars on 3G or 4G.
I would imagine a dedicated dongle would give you a connection like mine at the very least, as long as you have decent coverage.
Yeah I do this sometimes, it eats up so much data tho :3

What the fuck are these answers? I played League on a USB 3G internet broadband dongle for 2 years on a solid 200 ping (this was to NA) with no lag or DCing, it had better ping than my home internet had, lol.

>solid 200 ping
>200 ping
>solid

You're funny. Ever thought about quitting your day job and becoming a comedian? 200 ping is not "solid", in fact in games like LoL, 200 ping is the difference between catching that nidalee spear with your face, or taking one step to the left.
Or perhaps they meant "consistent" when they said "solid".
As a person who owns multiple 3g and 4g wifi "dongles", they are anything **but** consistent.
Damn alright! I'll have to do dome research

Short answer; no, you won't be able to play most likely at all. Even if you weren't disconnected constantly, the experience wouldn't be worth the effort, with massive lag, rubber banding and etc..
Even if it was like a really high quality one?

Depends, most games average at 50mb so if its you alone with an AWESOME connection to the internet provider e.g. if its Telstra/Optus/Virgin you should probably be in the area where they have strongest connection, I have a modem from Telstra, it is absolutely awesome and fast in the strongest area but when it isn't it can cause some lag. (I live on the boarder to the best connection, im just in the 2nd best ;-;)
How do I know which ISP is strongest in my area? I tried googling it but I couldn't find anything. I live in Sydenham 3037

what service are you going to use?

Well never mind that here are 3 providers strength (for your area).

Optus: Very Good (Outdoors)
Telstra: Good, there is a spot in the middle with medium internet connection for mobile modems (Telstra dodgy though)
Virgin: Very Strong (Outdoors)
So Optus and Virgin would be "bad" indoors?

I used to have a USB modem and it worked well enough to play online games (MMOs, MOBAs etc.) *IF* I was connecting to an Australian/Oceanic server and was playing from a large town or city. Even so ping was higher than usual (as if I was connecting to Europe/NA servers), occasional lag spikes etc.
Probably:
> the experience wouldn't be worth the effort
